altTitles.ja: 手塚治虫漫画全集未収録作品集

altTitles.ja-ro: Tezuka Osamu Manga Zenshu Mishuroku Sakuhinshu

description.en:
*Works that were not collected in the Tezuka 400 released in 1978 due to Tezuka losing the originals, but collected in the Tezuka bunko. The first volume has the work Hurricane Z as a bonus.*

The first volume includes:
- Galaxy Boy (Ginga Shounen) - Serialized from April 1953-February 1954 in Funny Book (Omoshiro Book)
- Cyrano the Magnificent (Cyrano de Bergerac) - Serialized from April to November 1953 in Shonen Illustrated (Shounen Gaho)
- President Bean (Mame Daitoryo) - Serialized from October 1953 to December 1954 in Adventure King (Bouken-O)
- [Hurricane Z](https://mangadex.org/title/62df625c-2ce4-4e5e-861a-4cc5c284094c/hurricane-z)

The second volume includes:

- Treasure Island (Takarajima) - Published as kashihon on March 1st, 1947 by Fuji Shuppansha
- Prof. Bat and Jim (Bat-hakase to Jim) published as kashihon on July 15th, 1947 by Arifundo 
- The Mysterious Dr. Koronko (Kaijin Koronko-hakase) - Published as kashihon on October 5th, 1947 by Doumei Shuppansha
- The Memoirs of Q-chan - serialized on May 25th, 1948 in Shinseikaku's publication Boy King of the Jungle (Mitsurin no Shounen-O)
- Piron-chan - Serialized in September 1960 in Kindergarten (Yochien)
- Hans and the Golden Hair (Hans to Kin no Kaminoke) - Serialized in the January 1949 supplement of Shonen Shojo Manga and Readings (Shounen Shoujo Manga to Yomimono supplement)
- The Tale of Wasps (Karyudobachi no Ohanashi) - Serialized in January 1957 in Second Grader's Study (Ningen no Gakushu) Supplemental Issue Stories For All with Beautiful Hearts
- Fabre's Insect Story (Fabre-sensei no mushimonogatari) - Serialized in Fifth Grader's Study (Gonen no Gakushu) in June 1958
- Drone Castle Story (Drone Shiro Monogatari) - serialized on January 10th, 1953 in Funny Book (Omoshiro Book)'s Extra New Year's Manga-Readings issue.
- The Weight of Biko (Biiko no Omori) - Serialized in Kodansha's Surprise Theater (Bikkuri Gekijo) on November 5th, 1954
- Suzumushi-hime - serialized in the October 1956 issue of Second Year's Study (Ninen no Gakushu)
- Birdcall Girl (Toriyose Shojo) -Serialized on January 20th, 1954 in Shojo Club's New Year's Special issue 
- Kurochoro's Adventure (Kurochoro no Bouken) - Serialized from April to October 1961 in Elementary Science Class 2 (Kagaku no Kyoshitsu Shokyu 2)
- The Compass to the Beans of Life (Inochi no Mame Jishaku) - Serialized on October 10th, 1955 in Asahi Shinbun's Elementary School 8th Special Reading and Manga issue
- The Dog Goes to the Moon (Wanko Getsu e Iku) - serialized in Funny Book (Omoshiro Book)'s Supplemental New Year's Manga Parade issue in January 1952
- I Use Ninjutsu (Boku ha ninjutsu tsukai) - Serialized on March 10th, 1955 in Asahi Shinbun's Elementary School 6th Special Reading and Manga issue
- Ghastly Jungle (Obake Jungle) - Serialized on January 25th, 1952 in Kid's Book's (Kodomo Book) Spring Special Issue
- Chikarashi-kun - Serialized in October 1956 in Yonen Club
- The Strange Journey (Kimyou na Dairyoko) - Serialized from July 21st, 1957 to March 31st 1958 in Asahi Junior.
- Miss Takarazuka - Serialized in August 1951 in Shojo Romance
- The Forefathers of Humanity (Ningen no Senzo) - Serialized on April 1st, 1961 in the Bessatsu Shonen Sunday Spring issue.
- Mars Story (Kasei Monogatari) - Serialized in Middle School Course (Chugaku Course's) Special Issue on January 15th 1960
- The Two Performers (Futari no Ensoka) - Serialized on August 15th, 1960 in Middle School  First Year Course (Chugaku Ichinen Course) Extra 2nd August Issue
- Wild Roses! When Will You Sing? (Nobara yo, itsu utau) - Serialized from December 1960 to April 20th 1961 in Shojo Sunday
- The Sun Upside Down (Taiyo ga Sakasama da) - Serialized in Middle School First Year Course (Chugaku Ichinen Course) Summer Holiday Special Issue


The third volume includes:
- Ghost Man (Yureio)
- Oldie's Treasure Island (Oyadi no Takarajima) - An earlier version of New Treasure Island.
- Til Victory Day (Shori no hi made) - Made during Tezuka's college days describing his time as the war went on.

biography.en:
Osamu Tezuka (手塚 治虫, b. 手塚 治, Tezuka Osamu; 3 November 1928 – 9 February 1989) was a Japanese manga artist, cartoonist, and animator. Born in Osaka Prefecture, his prolific output, pioneering techniques, and innovative redefinitions of genres earned him such titles as "the Father of Manga" (マンガの父, Manga no Chichi), "the Godfather of Manga" (マンガの教父, Manga no Kyōfu) and "the God of Manga" (マンガの神様, Manga no Kami-sama). 

Tezuka began what was known as the manga revolution in Japan with his [New Treasure Island](https://mangadex.org/title/63487511-434d-4a98-a1da-13bf80e9fcb8/new-treasure-island-1947) published in 1947. His output would spawn some of the most influential, successful, and well-received manga series including the children mangas [Astro Boy](https://mangadex.org/title/ca4c84bb-7272-45aa-a22d-dc1282b52372/tetsuwan-atom), [Princess Knight](https://mangadex.org/title/eb1b4f6f-8bc2-40a5-9398-768f5d4aea01/princess-knight-1953) and [Kimba the White Lion](https://mangadex.org/title/bad33763-70c6-40b7-8d14-190556fc55f0/jungle-emperor), and the adult-oriented series [Black Jack](https://mangadex.org/title/fd86eab2-f0f3-47d3-bce5-5628e97f37dc/black-jack), [Phoenix](https://mangadex.org/title/cc647d62-3a2c-474b-ac4e-844256ab185d/hi-no-tori), and [Buddha](https://mangadex.org/title/4e102d46-0a98-4249-8a42-98e4705b663e/buddha), all of which won several awards.

Tezuka died of stomach cancer in 1989. His death had an immediate impact on the Japanese public and other cartoonists. A museum was constructed in Takarazuka dedicated to his memory and life works, and Tezuka received many posthumous awards.

Osamu Tezuka (手塚 治虫, b. 手塚 治, Tezuka Osamu; 3 November 1928 – 9 February 1989) was a Japanese manga artist, cartoonist, and animator. Born in Osaka Prefecture, his prolific output, pioneering techniques, and innovative redefinitions of genres earned him such titles as "the Father of Manga" (マンガの父, Manga no Chichi), "the Godfather of Manga" (マンガの教父, Manga no Kyōfu) and "the God of Manga" (マンガの神様, Manga no Kami-sama). 

Tezuka began what was known as the manga revolution in Japan with his [New Treasure Island](https://mangadex.org/title/63487511-434d-4a98-a1da-13bf80e9fcb8/new-treasure-island-1947) published in 1947. His output would spawn some of the most influential, successful, and well-received manga series including the children mangas [Astro Boy](https://mangadex.org/title/ca4c84bb-7272-45aa-a22d-dc1282b52372/tetsuwan-atom), [Princess Knight](https://mangadex.org/title/eb1b4f6f-8bc2-40a5-9398-768f5d4aea01/princess-knight-1953) and [Kimba the White Lion](https://mangadex.org/title/bad33763-70c6-40b7-8d14-190556fc55f0/jungle-emperor), and the adult-oriented series [Black Jack](https://mangadex.org/title/fd86eab2-f0f3-47d3-bce5-5628e97f37dc/black-jack), [Phoenix](https://mangadex.org/title/cc647d62-3a2c-474b-ac4e-844256ab185d/hi-no-tori), and [Buddha](https://mangadex.org/title/4e102d46-0a98-4249-8a42-98e4705b663e/buddha), all of which won several awards.

Tezuka died of stomach cancer in 1989. His death had an immediate impact on the Japanese public and other cartoonists. A museum was constructed in Takarazuka dedicated to his memory and life works, and Tezuka received many posthumous awards.
